posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hail, mighty ECBers!

Well, WoG is down again, so, in an effort to prevent boredom, I started working on my own first STR-based Assassin build. Valerfor's most recent build got me thinking: if I were to do a STR-based Assassin, how would I do it? It's no secret that I prefer self-buffers; that's why I have many Bards / Wizards / Druids and especially Clerics in my NWN Builds folder, but that doesn't mean I don't appreciate the effectiveness of stealthers and sneak-types. However, I had never made a STR one. The first and most glaring weakness of such build types is LOW AC. So, unless you fight your enemies one at a time (which is not possible on many environments), you'll be in trouble. The second weakness that I see with this type of toon is dealing with True Seers. The third weakness is in the saves, but that can be mitigated with immunity gear, and the fourth weakness is dealing with sneak-immune types, but UMD scrolls and wands can help you there by adding Fire damage to your attacks, but that's worse for DEXers. In STR builds, you still have your STR damage to fall back on.

In Val's build, a couple of things were not right according to my personal preference:

1- Wielding a two-hander weapon: Well, Assassins paralyze their OOC (Out of Combat) opponents, so they need as many attacks as they can afford in their 1st flurry. Also, if you consider the bonus D6 of damage you get from Sneaks, you want as many attacks per round to apply them on as you can. A 2-hander, even though devastating for high-str toons, is not ideal for a STR-based Assassin IMO for those reasons. So I wanted a dual-wielder.
2- WM heavy investment for only 7 levels of it. This setup is only good against Dwarven Defenders, who are immune to Sneaks but not immune to Crits, so against DDs, it's a worthwhile investment. However, as was pointed out in Val's thread, many Sneak-immune monsters are also Crit-immune, so it doesn't add much to a build that's already excellent at doing damage to the non-immune.
3- Once it's engaged in combat, the only way to resolve it is to kill everyone. I personally like to hunt down casters first, to prevent them from buffing, then deal with the remaining mobs. Val's build would destroy the caster, then need either an Invisibility Potion or a Dust of Disappearance to reposition and do it again. That's doable, but really expensive. I prefer HiPS. Even more so because of this type of character's characteristic low AC.

So, I decided I would try a build with the following parameters:

1- Dual-wielding
2- At least 22 Assassin levels
3- At least 42 AB (40 Dual-wielding)
4- HiPS

So I came up with this guy, and I'm really pleased with the results:

If you look at this build more closely, you'll notice that I don't take Assassin as early as possible. That's because Rangers get the 2nd attack per round AND the animal companion at level 6. It's worth delaying that Assassin level to 7.

There are a few builds with this class combo, but only two are STR-based and they have much lower stats than this one. They end up at 36 and 38 AB dual-wielding against this guy's 41, but they both have a higher Death Attack DC. However, paralyzing enemies isn't as important for this guy as it'd be to a DEXer, because he can kill most things in one or two rounds, unless they are immune to his stuff. It's nice to paralyze things, definitely, but not vital. And if things get nasty, he can HiPS away and run.

Moor Stalker by dumediat is a dex-based EDer with a focus in Bows.

Unnamed Build by andymax is a DEXer with max DA DC.

Kalam Mekhar by RangerSG is a STR-based with Longsword focus (why??? lol)

Night Talon by TyrTemplar is a DEX-based character with good AB and dagger focus

Deathshadow by Mick Dagger is a dual-wielding MAX DEX elf with really good combat stats

Silent Assassin by DarkCenturion is the other STR-based one with 38 final AB

Shadow Stalker by Talamier is another DEXer but with focus on both Melee and Ranged attacks

The coolest thing here is that my build doesn't lose that much compared to DEXers, while having MUCH HIGHER stats than the STR-based ones. The sacrifice that I made for this was DA DC and HP. But, this guy wasn't built to tank, and his HiPS-oriented strat means he won't need to, so he can afford the extra offense. Before you get HiPS, the Assassin spell of Invisibility and Invisibility potions will do the trick for you, just make sure you have enough.

He'll be kind of hard to play until level 22, but it's doable if you know how to use your gold properly, then he'll grow into a great offensive toon. He will come in stealth, kill one enemy, HiPS, come back, kill another one, HiPS, and do this as many times as he needs without receiving much damage until all enemies are either paralyzed or dead. Against Sneak-crit-immune, his Darkfire or Flame Weapon wands will get the job done. He'll suffer the most against True-Seers. True-seeing crit-immune monsters will be his doom. True-seeing casters will be a problem also, but any casters that can't see him coming will drop dead in less than a round, for sure! True-seeing devcritters with high Discipline can also be a pain in the butt, but there are ways to deal with them :D. He will need friends to deal with these kinds of enemies, for the most part anyway. He can set and disable all deadly traps except gas, but those only come much later in the build, so I would say those skill points can be used somewhere else, I just put them there cuz I like setting traps. It's fun!

Summarizing: He has 11d6 DA damage dice, HiPS, IKD, Ranger dual-wield feats, full UMD and not such a heavy Armor Check penalty (he can only wear Light Armor for his Ranger dual-wielding feats to apply), so some DEX gear is in order. However, the coolest thing is that he has Camouflage, One with the Land, Cat's Grace and Mass Camouflage to increase his Hide and Move Silently scores to obscene totals of 75+! He is IMPOSSIBLE TO SEE by any non-true seer. All that while having a +11 unbuffed STR modifer to add to damage and 43 AB!

I hope you like him!

Take it EZ!

EDIT: I might as well suggest something that I saw as a possible tweak to take more advantage of your Evasion a little better. You can choose to exchange that last Assassin Bonus Feat for Epic Reflexes, which would increase your Reflex save and your chance to evade damage from traps and spells. But, I plan to give this guy a certain Padded Armor +5 that I already know where to get, so I'm going to try to cap his DEX, STR and INT with gear / buffs. He'll have Bull's Strength, Cat's Grace and Fox's Cunning Wands and Potions, as well as some very specific items that will allow him to have very close to capped scores on these 3 stats. But, since we're supposed to make generic builds here, this tweak could be interesting for some environments.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Ah, sorry. Thanks, Hip. My supposed issues were that:

1. At level 11 there's a carry-over of 7 points (ranks), but if Discipline (5) is taken at that level - which it can be because it's a Ranger level - there would be a save of 2. Then, at level 12, one need only take Discipline (1) rather than 6 points in the skill, and you'd still have a carry-over of 4 points. Thus, I suspect it was merely a hiccup in the distribution. So, no harm, no foul. Mea culpa.

2. This concerned the 2 levels of SD. The solution was a simple misread on my behalf. I had mistakenly read UMD (3) as a Save (3), which would have meant a different number of skill points available to each level of SD. This, of course, is not the case. Mea maxima culpa - and can you recommend an optician, please?

Apologies for doubting big Max and bothering you. (Although I still reckon my first point makes for an efficient tweak.)

Cheers

posts.content: In "Wheel of Time" all the Aiel women are depicted as having an especially heavy "knife" tucked under their belts, ready to use it on the first sign of an insult. Both these and also the "long-knives" are probably poetic license by the authors, trying to make these otherwise ordinary weapons seem more appropriate for the heroes of their tale. Of course, the descriptions are purposefully loose so that we can imagine them as we like, which is fine by me  ;)

rangersg wrote: Ahh good to see another connoisseur of the best epic fantasy written in the last decade.They were straight blades, so they wouldn't be kukris either. NWN didn't implement what they were, but Erikson was descriptive of how they looked. I'd say they were closest to a Jian. Perhaps on the shorter side of that range. But still long-sword length. When I was designing a PW, that was the model I used for my version of them, at least. And short swords, for Kalem? Blech. 
 
And I've been lurking for ages. Just never saw the need to post. Did this more on a lark than any need to defend my thinking. But thanks for the welcome. As I said, I'm aware it was not optimized. Total concept build. So I doubt it was ported. :P 

Been trying to play the new version of Aielund. But I can't get out of the Paladin or Blademaster rut I typically play that with. Had a bard/arcane archer that wrecked everything once too. So I'm playing a wizard, until my OCD causes me to grind my teeth with every change to a spell I cast where I *know* what is supposed to happen. lol
To be honest, I was actually looking for a Kalam-type build when I first came across this one (thinly veiled in some of my earlier postings). Demos' Ghost Viper (cited earlier in this thread) worked pretty well with a few tweaks, but had no Assassin levels, which made it somewhat different - though still fun to play. So I'm still trying to get there with the big man. Kalam and Quick Ben are still the second best duo in Erikson's saga when it comes to banter (first place has to go to Tehol and Bugg). Oh, and I quite agree about shortswords.

When it comes to Aielund, I love me some Monk (but to be fair, I love the class in most environments), if you fancy something different. But so many different types of build work there that there's no need to torture yourself!

And Katana duel-wielders mature late, even though I love the way he implements them and the quality blades he put in that set. Add in that Non-Kama/Fister Monk/WM builds mature later as is, and I'm afraid there'd be little enjoyment in much of the game. Even though I'd probably wreck house for that end with it. The No-Dachi was a good workaround, while still having the right flare. 

And Quick Ben is my favorite wizard not named Harry Dresden. Soul-merging, knuckle-shaving, Machiavellian that he is. :P

posts.author: rangersg
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: In "Wheel of Time" all the Aiel women are depicted as having an especially heavy "knife" tucked under their belts, ready to use it on the first sign of an insult. Both these and also the "long-knives" are probably poetic license by the authors, trying to make these otherwise ordinary weapons seem more appropriate for the heroes of their tale. Of course, the descriptions are purposefully loose so that we can imagine them as we like, which is fine by me  ;)
Well, not to derail the thread, but just to note: Erikson is an archaeologist by trade, and it shows in spades in his writing, so I'm sure he has some cultural antecedent. The Jian is the one that comes to me at first thought. The Seax is another possibility, though they were a tad too wide typically.
